editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

q.p:
THE charge of bla≈øphemy, which is put upon the record again≈øt the printer of this publication is not an accu≈øation of the ≈øervants of the crown, but comes before you ≈øanctioned by the oaths of a grand jury of the country. It ≈øtood for trial upon a former day; but it happening, as it frequently does, without any imputation upon the gentlemen named in the pannel, that a ≈øufficient number did not appear to con≈øtitute a full ≈øpecial jury, I thought it my duty to withdraw the cau≈øe from trial, till I could have the opportunity which is now open to me of addre≈ø≈øing my≈øelf to you, who were originally appointed to try it. I pur≈øued this cour≈øe, however, from no jealou≈øy of the common juries appointed by the laws for the ordinary ≈øervice of the court, ≈øince my whole life has been one continued experience of their virtues; but becau≈øe I thought it of great importance, that tho≈øe who were
to decide upon a cau≈øe ≈øo very momentous to the public, ≈øhould have the highe≈øt po≈ø≈øible qualifications for the deci≈øion: that they ≈øhould not only be men capable from their educations of forming an enlightened judgment, but that their ≈øituations ≈øhould be ≈øuch as to bring them within the full view of their enlightened country, to which, in character and in e≈øtimation, they were in their own turns to be re≈øpon≈øible.

Not having the honour, Gentlemen, to be ≈øworn for the king as one of his coun≈øel, it has fallen much oftener to my lot to defend indictments for libels, than to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in the pro≈øecution of them. But I feel no embarra≈ø≈øment from that recollection; ≈øince I ≈øhall not be found to-day to expre≈øs a ≈øentiment, or to utter an expre≈ø≈øion, incon≈øi≈øtent with tho≈øe invaluable principles for which I have uniformly contended in the defence of others. Nothing that I have ever ≈øaid, either profe≈ø≈øionally or per≈øonally, for the liberty of the pre≈øs, do I mean to-day to contradict or counteract. On the contrary, I de≈øire to preface the very ≈øhort di≈øcour≈øe I have to make to you with reminding you, that it is your mo≈øt ≈øolemn duty to take care that it ≈øuffers no injury in your hands. A free and unlicen≈øed pre≈øs (in the ju≈øt and legal ≈øen≈øe of the expre≈ø≈øion) has led to all the ble≈ø≈øings both of religion and government, which Great Britain or any part of the world at this moment enjoys, and is calculated ≈øtill farther to advance mankind to higher degrees of civilization and happine≈øs. But this freedom, like every other, mu≈øt be limited to be enjoyed, and like every human advantage, may be defeated by its abu≈øe.

Gentlemen! the defendant ≈øtands indicted for having publi≈øhed this book, which I have only read from the obligations of profe≈ø≈øional duty, and which I ro≈øe from the reading of with a≈øtoni≈øhment and di≈øgu≈øt. Standing here with all the privileges belonging to the highe≈øt coun≈øel for the crown, I ≈øhall
be entitled to reply to any defence that ≈øhall be made for the publication. I ≈øhall wait with patience till I hear it. Indeed, if I were to anticipate the defence which I hear and read of, it would be defaming by anticipation the learned coun≈øel who is to make it. For if I am to collect it, even from a formal notice given to the pro≈øecutors in the cour≈øe of the proceedings, I have to expect, that, in≈øtead of a defence conducted according to the rules and principles of Engli≈øh law and ju≈øtice, the foundation of all our laws, and the ≈øanctions of all our ju≈øtice, are to be ≈øtruck at and in≈øulted. What is the force of that juri≈ødiction which enables the court to ≈øit in judgment? What but the oath which his Lord≈øhip, as well as your≈øelves, have ≈øworn upon the go≈øpel to fulfil? Yet in the king's court, where his Maje≈øty is him≈øelf al≈øo ≈øworn to admini≈øter the ju≈øtice of England‚Äîin the king's court‚Äîwho receives his high authority under a ≈øolemn oath to maintain the Chri≈øtian religion, as it is promulgated by God in the Holy Scriptures, I am neverthele≈øs called upon as coun≈øel for the pro≈øecution, to produce a certain book de≈øcribed in the indictment to be the Holy Bible. No man de≈øerves to be upon the rolls of the court, who dares, as an attorney, to put his name to ≈øuch a notice. It is an in≈øult to the authority and dignity of the court of which he is an officer; ≈øince it ≈øeems to call in que≈øtion the very foundations of its juri≈ødiction. If this is to be the ≈øpirit and temper of the defence; if, as I collect from that array of books which are ≈øpread upon the benches behind me, this publication is to be vindicated by an attack of all the truths which the Chri≈øtian religion promulgates to mankind, let it be remembered that ≈øuch an argument was neither ≈øugge≈øted nor ju≈øtified by any thing ≈øaid by me on the part of the pro≈øecution. In this ≈øtage of the proceedings, I ≈øhall call for reverence to the Sacred Scriptures, not from their merits, unbounded as they are, but from their authority
in a Chri≈øtian country‚Äînot from the obligations of con≈øcience, but from the rules of law. For my own part, Gentlemen, I have been ever deeply devoted to the truths of Chri≈øtianity; and my firm belief in the Holy Go≈øpel is by no means owing to the prejudices of education (though I was religiou≈øly educated by the be≈øt of parents), but ari≈øes from the fulle≈øt and mo≈øt continued reflections of my riper years and under≈øtanding. It forms at this moment the great con≈øolation of a life, which, as a ≈øhadow, mu≈øt pa≈øs away; and without it, indeed, I ≈øhould con≈øider my long cour≈øe of health and pro≈øperity (perhaps too long and too uninterrupted to be good for any man) only as the du≈øt which the wind ≈øcatters, and rather as a ≈ønare than as a ble≈ø≈øing. Much, however, as I wi≈øh to ≈øupport the authority of Scripture from a rea≈øoned con≈øideration of it, I ≈øhall repre≈øs that ≈øubject for the pre≈øent. But if the defence ≈øhall be as I have ≈øu≈øpected, to bring them at all into argument or que≈øtion, I ≈øhall then fulfil a duty which I owe not only to the court, as coun≈øel for the pro≈øecution, but to the public, to ≈øtate what I feel and know concerning the evidences of that religion which is reviled without being examined, and denied without being under≈øtood.

I am well aware that by the communications of a free pre≈øs, all the errors of mankind, from age to age, have been di≈ø≈øipated and di≈øpelled; and I recollect that the world, under the banners of reformed Chri≈øtianity, has ≈øtruggled through per≈øecution to the noble eminence on which it ≈øtands at this moment, ≈øhedding the ble≈ø≈øings of humanity and ≈øcience upon the nations of the earth. It may be a≈øked, by what means the reformation would have been effected, if the books of the reformers had been ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, and the errors of condemned and exploded ≈øuper≈øtitions had been ≈øupported as unque≈øtionable by the ≈øtate, founded upon tho≈øe very ≈øuper≈øtitions formerly, as it is at pre≈øent upon the doctrines
of the e≈øtabli≈øhed church? Or how, upon ≈øuch principles, any reformation, civil or religious can in future be effected? The ≈øolution is ea≈øy:‚Äî Let us examine what are the genuine principles of the liberty of the pre≈øs, as they regard writings upon general ≈øubjects, unconnected with the per≈øonal reputations of private men, which are wholly foreign to the pre≈øent inquiry. They are full of ≈øimplicity, and are brought as near perfection, by the law of England, as, perhaps, is con≈øi≈øtent with any of the frail in≈øtitutions of mankind.

Although every community mu≈øt e≈øtabli≈øh ≈øupreme authorities, founded upon fixed principles, and mu≈øt give high powers to magi≈øtrates to admini≈øter laws for the pre≈øervation of the government it≈øelf, and for the ≈øecurity of tho≈øe who are to be protected by it: yet, as infallibility and perfection belong neither to human e≈øtabli≈øhments nor to human individuals, it ought to be the policy of all free e≈øtabli≈øhments, as it is mo≈øt peculiarly the principle of our own con≈øtitution, to permit the mo≈øt unbounded freedom of di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, even by detecting errors in the con≈øtitution or admini≈øtration of the very government it≈øelf, ≈øo as that decorum is ob≈øerved, which every ≈øtate mu≈øt exact from its ≈øubjects, and which impo≈øes no re≈øtraint upon any intellectual compo≈øition, fairly, hone≈øtly, and decently addre≈ø≈øed to the con≈øciences and under≈øtandings of men. Upon this principle, I have an unque≈øtionable right (a right which the be≈øt ≈øubjects have exerci≈øed) to examine the principles and ≈øtructure of the con≈øtitution, and by fair, manly rea≈øoning, to que≈øtion the practice of its admini≈øtrators. I have a right to con≈øider and to point out errors in the one or in the other; and not merely to rea≈øon upon their exi≈øtence, but to con≈øider the means of their reformation. By ≈øuch free, well-intentioned, mode≈øt, and dignified communication of ≈øentiments and opinions, all nations have been gradually improved, and milder laws and purer
religions have been e≈øtabli≈øhed. The ≈øame principles, which vindicate civil contentions hone≈øtly directed, extend their protection to the ≈øharpe≈øt controver≈øies on religious faiths. This rational and legal cour≈øe of improvement was recognized and ratified by Lord Kenyon, as the law of England, in a late trial at Guildhall, when he looked back with gratitude to the labours of the reformers, as the fountains of our religious emancipation, and of the civil ble≈ø≈øings that followed in their train. The Engli≈øh con≈øtitution, indeed, does not ≈øtop ≈øhort in the toleration of religious opinions, but liberally extends it to practice. It permits every man, EVEN PUBLICLY to wor≈øhip God according to his own con≈øcience, though in marked di≈ø≈øent from the national e≈øtabli≈øhment, ≈øo as he profe≈ø≈øes the general faith, which is the ≈øanction of all our moral duties, and the only pledge of our ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the ≈øy≈øtem which con≈øtitutes a ≈øtate. Is not this ≈øy≈øtem of freedom of controver≈øy, and freedom of wor≈øhip, ≈øufficient for all the purpo≈øes of human happine≈øs and improvement? And can it be nece≈ø≈øary for either, that the law ≈øhould hold out indemnity to tho≈øe who wholly abjure and revile the government of their country, or the religion on which it re≈øts for its foundation? I expect to hear, in an≈øwer to what I am now ≈øaying, much that will offend me. My learned friend, from the difficulties of his ≈øituation, which I know, from experience, how to feel for very ≈øincerely, may be driven to advance propo≈øitions which it may be my duty, with much freedom, to reply to; and the law will ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ction that freedom. But will not the ends of ju≈øtice be completely an≈øwered by that right, to point out the errors of his di≈øcour≈øe in terms that are decent, and calculated to expo≈øe its defects; or will any argument ≈øuffer, or will public ju≈øtice be impeded, becau≈øe neither private honour and ju≈øtice, nor public decorum, would endure my telling my very learned friend, that he
was a fool, a liar, and a ≈øcoundrel, in the face of the court, becau≈øe I differed from him in argument or opinion? This is ju≈øt the di≈øtinction between a book of free legal controver≈øy and the book which I am arraigning before you. Every man has a legal right to inve≈øtigate, with mode≈øty and decency, controver≈øial points of the Chri≈øtian religion; but no man, con≈øi≈øtently with a law, which only exi≈øts under its ≈øanctions, has a right not only broadly to deny its very exi≈øtence, but to pour forth a ≈øhocking and in≈øulting invective, which the lowe≈øt e≈øtabli≈øhments in the gradations of civil authority ought not to be permitted to ≈øuffer, and which ≈øoon would be borne down by in≈øolence and di≈øobedience, if they did.

The ≈øame principle pervades the whole ≈øy≈øtem of the law, not merely in its ab≈øtract theory, but in its daily and mo≈øt applauded practice.‚ÄîThe intercour≈øe between the ≈øexes, and which, properly regulated, not only continues, but humanizes and adorns our natures, is the foundation of all the thou≈øand romances, plays, and novels, which are in the hands of every body. Some of them lead to the confirmation of every virtuous principle; others, though with the ≈øame profe≈ø≈øion, addre≈øs the imagination in a manner to lead the pa≈ø≈øions into dangerous exce≈ø≈øes. But though the law does not nicely di≈øcriminate the various ≈øhades which di≈øtingui≈øh the≈øe works from one another, ≈øo as that it ≈øuffers many to pa≈øs, through its liberal ≈øpirit, that upon principle might be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, would it or does it tolerate, or does any decent man contend that it ought to pa≈øs by unpuni≈øhed, libels of the mo≈øt ≈øhamele≈øs ob≈øcenity, manife≈øtly pointed to debauch innocence, and to bla≈øt and poi≈øon the morals of the ri≈øing generation? This is only another illu≈øtration to demon≈øtrate the obvious di≈øtinction between the work of an author, who fairly exerci≈øes the powers of his mind, in inve≈øtigating doctrinal points in the religion of any
country, and him who attacks the rational exi≈øtence of every religion, and brands with ab≈øurdity and folly the ≈øtate which ≈øanctions, and the obedient tools who cheri≈øh the delu≈øion. But this publication appears to me to be as mi≈øchievous and cruel in its probable effects, as it is manife≈øtly illegal in its principles; becau≈øe it ≈øtrikes at the be≈øt, ≈øometimes, alas! the only refuge and con≈øolation amid≈øt the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes and afflictions of the world. The poor and humble, whom it affects to pity, may be ≈øtabbed to the heart by it. They have more occa≈øion for firm hopes beyond the grave, than tho≈øe who have greater comforts to render life delightful. I can conceive a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed but virtuous man, ≈øurrounded by children, looking up to him for bread when he has none to give them, ≈øinking under the la≈øt day's labour, and unequal to the next, yet ≈øtill looking up with confidence to the hour when all tears ≈øhall be wiped from the eyes of affliction, bearing the burden laid upon him by a my≈øterious Providence which he adores, and looking forward with exultation to the revealed promi≈øes of his Creator, when he ≈øhall be greater than the greate≈øt, and happier than the happie≈øt of mankind. What a change in ≈øuch a mind might not be wrought by ≈øuch a mercile≈øs publication? Gentlemen! whether the≈øe remarks are the overcharged declamations of an accu≈øing coun≈øel, or the ju≈øt reflections of a man anxious for the public freedom, which is be≈øt ≈øecured by the morals of a nation, will be be≈øt ≈øettled by an appeal to the pa≈ø≈øages in the work, that are ≈øelected by the indictment for your con≈øideration and judgment. You are at liberty to connect them with every context and ≈øequel, and to be≈øtow upon them the milde≈øt interpretation. [Here Mr. Er≈økine read and commented upon ≈øever ‚Ä¢ l of the ≈øelected pa≈ø≈øages, and then proceeded as follows:] ‚ÄîGentlemen, it would be u≈øele≈øs and di≈øgu≈øting to enumerate the other pa≈ø≈øages within the ≈øcope of the indictment. How any man can rationally vindicate
the publication of ≈øuch a book, in a country where the Chri≈øtian religion is the very foundation of the law of the land, I am totally at a lo≈øs to conceive, and have no ideas for the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of. How is a tribunal, who≈øe whole juri≈ødiction is founded upon the ≈øolemn belief and practice of what is denied as fal≈øehood, and reprobated as impiety, to deal with ≈øuch an anomalous defence? Upon what principle is it even offered to the court, who≈øe authority is contemned and mocked at? If the religion propo≈øed to be called in que≈øtion, is not previou≈øly adopted in belief and ≈øolemnly acted upon, what authority has the court to pa≈øs any judgment at all of acquittal or condemnation? Why am I now, or upon any other occa≈øion, to ≈øubmit to your lord≈øhip's authority? Why am I now, or at any time, to addre≈øs twelve of my equals, as I am now addre≈ø≈øing you, with reverence and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion? Under what ≈øanction are the witne≈ø≈øes to give their evidence, without which there can be no trial? Under what obligations can I call upon you, the jury repre≈øenting your country, to admini≈øter ju≈øtice? Surely upon no other than that you are ≈øworn to admini≈øter it under the oaths you have taken. The whole judicial fabric, from the king's ≈øovereign authority to the lowe≈øt office of magi≈øtracy, has no other foundation. The whole is built, both in form and ≈øub≈øtance, upon the ≈øame oath of every one of its mini≈øters to do ju≈øtice AS GOD SHALL HELP THEM HEREAFTER. What God? And what hereafter? That God, undoubtedly, who has commanded kings to rule, and judges to decree with ju≈øtice; who has ≈øaid to witne≈ø≈øes, not by the voice of nature, but in revealed commandments‚ÄîTHOU SHALT NOT BEAR FALSE TESTIMONY AGAINST THY NEIGHBOUR; and who has enforced obedience to them by the revelation of the unutterable ble≈ø≈øings which ≈øhall attend their ob≈øervance, and the awful puni≈øhments which ≈øhall await upon their tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion. But it
≈øeems, this is an age of rea≈øon, and the time and the per≈øon are at la≈øt arrived, that are to di≈ø≈øipate the errors which have over≈øpread the pa≈øt generations of ignorance. The believers in Chri≈øtianity are many, but it belongs to the few that are wi≈øe to correct their credulity. Belief is an act of rea≈øon, and ≈øuperior rea≈øon may, therefore, dictate to the weak. In running the mind along the long li≈øt of ≈øincere and devout Chri≈øtians, I cannot help lamenting, that Newton had not lived to this day, to have had his ≈øhallowne≈øs filled up with this new flood of light.‚ÄîBut the ≈øubject is too awful for irony. I will ≈øpeak plainly and directly. Newton was a Chri≈øtian! Newton, who≈øe mind bur≈øt forth from the fetters ca≈øt by nature upon our finite conceptions‚ÄîNewton, who≈øe ≈øcience was truth, and the foundation of who≈øe knowledge of it was philo≈øophy‚Äînot tho≈øe vi≈øionary and arrogant pre≈øumptions, which too often u≈øurp its name, but philo≈øophy re≈øting upon the ba≈øis of mathematics, which, like figures, cannot lie‚ÄîNewton, who carried the line and rule to the uttermo≈øt barriers of creation, and explored the principles by which, no doubt, all created matter is held together and exi≈øts. But this extraordinary man, in the mighty reach of his mind, overlooked, perhaps, the errors, which a minuter inve≈øtigation of the created things on this earth might have taught him, of the e≈ø≈øence of his Creator. What ≈øhall then be ≈øaid of the great Mr. Boyle, who looked into the organic ≈øtructure of all matter, even to the brute inanimate ≈øub≈øtances which the foot treads on? Such a man may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have been equally qualified with Mr. Paine to look up through nature to nature's God. Yet the re≈øult of all his contempla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on was the mo≈øt confirmed and devout belief in all which the other holds in contempt, as de≈øpicable and drivelling ≈øuper≈øtition.‚ÄîBut this error might, perhaps, ari≈øe from a want of due attention to the
